docs.lead_paragraph: There is never enough time or money; this much we all know. Yet a new study finds that when people estimate how much of each they will have in the future, they are consistently more likely to overestimate their time than their dollars. Dr. Gal Zauberman of the University of North Carolina and Dr. John Lynch of Duke, professors of marketing, have found that future expenditures of time are always psychologically discounted -- that is, a future disbursement of time seems to be worth less than an outlay of time in the present.

headline.main: Future Shock Concept Gets a Personal Twist

docs.abstract: Dr Gal Zauberman of University of North Carolina and Dr John Lynch of Duke University lead study that shows individuals view future free time as more abundant then it is in their present everyday life; study, which is published in Journal of Experimental Psychology: General, finds that individuals believe they will have substantially more time in the future, but not always more wealth; asserts that psychological tendency can lead to overscheduling and support volunteerism (M)
docs.snippet: A new study finds that when people estimate how much of each they will have in the future, they are consistently more likely to overestimate their time than their dollars.

docs.lead_paragraph: Reports that a New York man may be carrying a rare and possibly virulent strain of H.I.V. have focused new attention on the biological relationship between the virus and methamphetamine, a drug that has become increasingly entwined in the spread of sexually transmitted diseases in cities from San Francisco to Miami to New York. Although methamphetamine, often called crystal meth or speed, is most troubling to health officials because of its role in blotting out inhibitions and fueling high-risk sexual behavior, experts say they are also grappling with mounting evidence that the drug by itself may increase a person's susceptibility to infection by crippling immune function and facilitating disease transmission.

headline.main: Scientists Explore Meth's Role in Immune System

docs.abstract: Several recent studies support theory that effects of using methamphetamine weaken defenses against AIDS virus and leave drug user particularly susceptible to infection and transmission of infection; researchers had previously thought meth's impact was only through risky sexual behavior that users typically engage in, but new research suggests physical reasons behind high rate of AIDS infection; research discussed (M)
docs.snippet: Reports that a New York man may be carrying a rare and possibly virulent strain of H.I.V. have focused new attention on the biological relationship between the virus and methamphetamine.

docs.lead_paragraph: The coolest person I have ever known was Scottie Fosberg, the nurse who operated the heart-lung machine at the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston, where I was training with Dr. Dwight Harken , a tough, brilliant pioneer in cardiac surgery. It was the early 1960's, those inchoate days of open-heart surgery. Scottie was smart and pretty with an oval face, eyes very brown, solid body. She knew the ropes, having worked with Dr. Harken for six years. And she was kind to the trainees.

headline.main: Cool Heads and Cold Hearts in the Days of Pioneers

docs.abstract: Dr Larry Zaroff Cases column describes scene during early open-heart surgery in 1960's; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Remembering a doctor and nurse duo who taught some Russian visitors what it meant to be cool-headed in the operating room.

docs.lead_paragraph: The so-called treatment gap for women with heart disease -- the tendency for doctors to treat them less aggressively than men -- may be narrowing, but many women, it seems, are still neglecting a simple step for their own health. Two studies examining these disparities were presented last week at an American Heart Association conference in Orlando, Fla., on women, heart disease and stroke.

headline.main: A Small Step for Women's Hearts

docs.abstract: Two studies presented at American Heart Assn conference show that although disparity between treatment for heart disease and stroke for women and men is narrowing, women are not routinely taking low-dose aspirin recommended by their doctors; one study was led by Dr Jeffrey S Berger of Beth Israel Medical Center; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: The so-called treatment gap for women with heart disease may be narrowing, but many women are still neglecting a simple step for their own health.

docs.lead_paragraph: Among famous inventors, Leo H. Sternbach may not immediately leap to mind. But this May in Akron, Ohio, Dr. Sternbach, who is 96, will be inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame. He holds more than 240 patents, but perhaps his most famous invention, in collaboration with colleagues, is a chemical compound called diazepam, better known by its brand name, Valium.

headline.main: A Host of Anxiety Drugs, Begat by Valium

docs.abstract: Inventor Leo H Sternbach, who is best known for his collaboration in developing chemical compound Valium, is to be inducted into National Inventors Hall of Fame; Valium is still widely used today despite development of other drugs to treat anxiety that do not have as many potential harmful side effects; Dr Eric Hollander, Mount Sinai School of Medicine clinical psychopharmacology director, holds that Valium continues to have benefits, but must be used correctly to best help patient; Valium is considered by many to be American cultural icon (M)
docs.snippet: Benzodiazepines - like Valium and its offspring - have gone through controversy, but have never disappeared.

docs.lead_paragraph: Of all the debates surrounding the diagnosis and treatment of breast cancer in recent decades, the most persistent and perplexing one involves a very early cancer called D.C.I.S., or ductal carcinoma in situ. This cancer is noninvasive, confined to the milk duct where it arose. Some of these cancers will eventually become invasive, others never will. In autopsies, about 10 percent of women are found to have a ductal carcinoma that never became evident.

headline.main: A Breast Cancer With a Built-In Quandary

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses ductal carcinoma in situ, early breast cancer, and various treatment options available to women discovered to have condition; cancer is noninvasive, but can develop into invasive cancer, so many women choose aggressive treatments including radiation, lumpectomy, and mastectomy; few women diagnosed with ductal carcinoma die of breast cancer, which can make surgical decision even more difficult; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: The most persistent and perplexing debate surrounding the diagnosis and treatment of breast cancer involves a very early cancer called D.C.I.S.

docs.lead_paragraph: For six months last year, Jill Wilson had a persistent cough. ''It was so harsh and deep that I broke ribs,'' she said. Various medical specialists told Ms. Wilson, an otherwise fit 60-year-old, that she had bronchitis, asthma, allergies and perhaps even a serious lung disorder known as interstitial pulmonary fibrosis.

headline.main: Enduring And Painful, Pertussis Leaps Back

docs.abstract: Pertussis, which is commonly thought of as childhood illness, is growing threat to adult and teen health in US with 18,957 cases reported in 2004, up from 9,784 in 2003; is highly contagious and requires health officials to take active role in containing any outbreaks; there is no approved vaccine for adolescents and adults in US, but drug companies are working to get Food and Drug Administration approval for several vaccines on market in Europe; diminished immunity is considered to be primary cause for resurgence since vaccine, which is given to infants, has limited effectiveness of 5 to 10 years; best treatment for whooping cough is early intervention with antibiotic erythromycin; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Commonly thought of as a childhood illness controlled by vaccination, pertussis, or whooping cough, is a growing health threat in the U.S.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Stepping on a rusty nail can cause tetanus. THE FACTS -- Any 10-year-old can explain the link between rusty nails and tetanus. But few people realize that the bacteria that cause it are widespread and that the disease has less to do with rust than with the nature of a wound. Clostridia bacteria, the family of C. tetani, can be found in soil, dust, feces and on the skin. They reproduce only in the absence of oxygen, so any wound deep enough can become a breeding ground.
docs.abstract: Developing tetanus is linked more closely with depth of puncture than with material that produces puncture wound; stepping on rusty or clean nails can cause tetanus; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Tetanus has less to do with rust than with the nature of a wound.

docs.lead_paragraph: Cellphones with cameras can help doctors treat the sores and skin ulcers that are the bane of many elderly patients, according to a study released yesterday. The study, published in The Archives of Dermatology, found that two doctors viewing images taken with a phone's camera and sent by e-mail had reliably reached the same conclusion as a doctor examining the patient in person.

headline.main: Skin Sores? Dial D for Diagnosis

docs.abstract: Dr Ralph Peter Braun of University Hospital, Geneva, leads study published in Archives of Dermatology that shows benefits of using cell phone photographs to help aid workers in field communicate with doctors to diagnose and treat skin sores and ulcers; phone can also be used to ask specific questions of patients on location without office visits; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Cellphones with cameras can help doctors treat the sores and skin ulcers that are the bane of many elderly patients, according to a newly released study.

docs.lead_paragraph: Walking as little as a block or two a day can make a big difference for older women who are in poor health, a new study reports. The research, which was published in The Journal of the American Geriatric Society, involved 800 women over 65 who reported limits in performing some common tasks of daily living. The study's lead author, Dr. Eleanor M. Simonsick of the National Institute on Aging, said the sample roughly represented the least healthy third of the population.
docs.abstract: Dr Eleanor M Simonsick of National Institute on Aging leads research that shows older women benefit by walking as little as two blocks per day; study, which is published in Journal of the American Geriatric Society, shows largest health benefits for women with most severe health problems; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Walking as little as a block or two a day can make a big difference for older women who are in poor health, a new study reports.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN GERIATRIC SOCIETY
